0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Bacterial conjunctivitis: 1 drop instilled in affected eye(s) three times daily for 7 days

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy in children under 1 year of age has not been established
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis: (1 year or older) 1 drop instilled in affected eye(s) three times daily for 7 days

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• topical ophthalmic use only; do not inject into the eye
  • report adverse events to Bausch & Lomb at 1-800-323-0000 or the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Besifloxacin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Besifloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibacterial which inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV resulting in impaired replication, transcription, and repair of bacterial DNA and impairment of the partitioning of the chromosomal DNA during bacterial cell division.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Ophthalmic
  • shake inverted closed bottle once before each use
  • do not use with contact lenses

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• resolution of clinical symptoms of conjunctivitis (eg, redness, itching, swelling, discharge from eye) is indicative of efficacy
  • slit-lamp biomicroscopy and fluorescein staining, if super-infection is suspected following prolonged use

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid contact lenses if signs/symptoms of bacterial conjunctivitis appear.
  • Drug may cause conjunctival redness.
  • Drug may cause blurred vision, eye pain, eye irritation, eye pruritus, and headache.
  • Instruct patient on proper instillation technique.
